title: L-Earning Bazaar: Web3 Integration

f6_assessments.q0: The content of the proposal is to build a comprehensive educational platform on Cardano. Anyone interested and knowledgeable in their area of ​​expertise can apply to become a teacher on this platform and provide their course level. Students can enroll in the course they like and a DID (Digital ID) mechanism will record the student's achievement after successfully completing the course they have registered for. Similarly with teachers, DID will also record feedbacks and evaluations from students so that teachers can improve the quality of their lessons. This is an interaction in the application of the DID mechanism that Atala Prism designed. This platform will be further expanded by its self-sustaining model (through the Point incentive mechanism that the proposal presents), attract more developers to learn if they find a course they're looking for. Also attract more users in the community to engage with the platform. The proposal fully meets the criteria given by the "Dapps, Products & Integrations" challenge. Therefore I completely agree with the impact of the project.

f6_assessments.q0:
This is a proposal for a somewhat decentralized approach to education, where classes and participation are effectively "tokenized" (here called points, later to be represented as tokens, for now represented as ADA).  So students pay teachers, teachers reward students, charitable or organizational funding supports teachers and students, and a side-protocol generates an NFT admissions process for rewarding participants and teachers of "special" classes (here described as perhaps guest lectures...i.e. event style classes with limited engagement ability but high value).

All in all the protocols described here seem like they would be functional, and in the process deliver an education marketplace to Cardano that was distributive in nature.  However I have some concerns about the governance of these desirable distributive characteristics.  There seems to be an assumption being made here about the classes being offered, specifically that they are adequate for learning.  But the framework described here would potentially allow anyone to be a teacher (a good thing, IMO, as it allows us to capture the edge knowledge).  While there appears to be a mechanic in place to curate value over time (it wasn't entirely clear, but it seems that a class that isn't returning value to the students who have already paid would "rank" lower than other classes) the issue becomes students trusting enough to spend their points in the first place in order for that data to come in.  This is a debilitating feature, IMO.

However, they have described as sort of pilot program when launching this platform, where they will manually create and curate a handful of classes aimed at Cardano and Web3 developers and language (human) classes.  These would be the first classes, and in the process of creating and staffing them they may be able to discover the requirements needed to onboard effective educators.  In turn they envision a form of scaling for the project where students could be verified by their teachers, allowing the student to teach the classes they have taken, thus expanding capacity of curated classes.

Because the creation of an decentralized education marketplace could have a huge impact in terms of transactions generated as well as cultivating the environment for future participation and contribution, I feel that the score here is solid.  However, due to issues regarding what the actual effectiveness of such decentralized efforts would be, I am removing one star for a 4 stars Impact.
f6_assessments.q1:
To start with, this team seems to be well structured to take on this task.  There is a mix of business and education experience and good familiarity with the main DLT tech they will be working with (token integration and NFTs at the beginning, DIDs and token engineering on the long term roadmap).

The timeline is well described, though I was looking for milestones regarding the onboarding of the first classes, and it was less clear.  In breaking down the issue of how they will get effective classes onboarded in a distributed protocol, the timeline highlights the initial stages of actually building these protocols.  It really highlighted for me how much thought has been given to structuring the incentives versus the base content or value creation protocol.  As mentioned in Impact, there just seems to be this assumption here about the value of the classes provided, but this really needs a vetting procedure to have confidence in this plan.  The whole project has a timeline of 5 months, and the deliverable from the first month is "Requirements and specifications" but there isn't enough context to understand whether this includes onboarding requirements, especially given that they are creating the actual pilot courses themselves.

I do appreciate, however, the attention given to the incentives structure.  In any distributed work environment sustainability and "liveness" are critical, and often ignored, and these are the issues this team is tackling.  But I caution the team not to get the cart before the horse.  The absolute core of this protocol is not the incentives, but the classes, and distributing that work in an effective way is what will separate this project from the rest as a true Web3 experience.

The budget lines up well, especially in terms of designing and building an innovative incentives protocol.  It is a bit out of sync with the overall timeline, as there is a budget item that covers 6 months, while the timeline states it is a 5 month project.  However the line item is for an advisor, and some of their metrics will need to be tracked beyond target completion, so that could explain the lack of alignment.  As a general observation, the actual details of the budget could have been broken down more, and it would have clarified issues like this, which also includes the funding of a "Help Desk" whose function isn't well described elsewhere in the proposal.  I can imagine what it is and why it is needed, but some details would be helpful.

Because the team shows relevant experience, and because some detail has been provided for timelines and milestones, there is some basis here for feasibility of an incentives protocol Proof of Concept and Pilot.  However, due to a lack of details regarding critical components of what they intend to deliver, as well as a lack of clarity in budget items, I can neither agree nor disagree with the Feasibility of this proposal. 3 stars.
f6_assessments.q2:
The overall success metric is clouded by the jostling noted earlier about the incentives structure taking priority over the class content curation.  The result is a statement which is too abstract (content to be refined in the context of constructive competition) as well as likely unachievable (by stating that they will reach 128 million child laborers, is this a hyperbolic impact statement or something they intend to measure and attain?  The latter seems unlikely and the former isn't helpful as a metric.)

They note that they will maintain a discord server to follow the progress of the project, which is helpful, however much more is needed.  There needs to be some relevant KPIs that actually measure progress towards specific milestones in the project (it may be possible to extract these manually from the timeline, but only the proposers can establish which ones are within their scope for tracking).

They do indicate a willingness to tweet out a weekly development report which could be extremely effective.  Catalyst only accepts a monthly report, so weekly reporting to the community at large could bridge the gap and keep the project on track.

Because the project has provided means of communication and a willingness for transparency, but because there is a lack of details regarding what will be reported and how completion of the project is to be gauged, I can neither agree nor disagree with it being auditable.  3 stars.
